>>2545927
water treatment plants are using reversed layers because they wash the filters by backflow and pump air through them from bottom through special nozzles
the water is not sterile, you will have living aerobic bacteria eating gunk and cleaning water
you don't want anaerobic bacteria because they make the water smell like sewer - that's why the sand needs to be supplied with oxygen
bacteria form a film on top that gets scraped off periodically
the filters need to be washed every couple of days, you can't simply change 100 tons of sand every other day because you can crap living in it

t. water treatment major

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2545996
okay think about it.
do you think water flows through gaps in large rocks, or very fine sand, faster?
the answer is it flows faster through the gaps between large rocks.
the filter is a screen. stuff that is smaller than the gaps between the material goes through. larger stuff stays above it.
stuff that does not go through the holes, clogs the holes. water now cannot go through that hole.
if you could pre-filter the larger bulkier shit earlier then your finer filter wont get clogged so quickly.

Sorry to keep you waiting

NEC 200.7(C) Circuits of 50 Volts or More
The use of insulation that is white or gray or that has three continuous white or gray stripes for other than a grounded conductor for circuits of 50 volts or more shall be permitted only as in (1) and (2).
If part of a cable assembly that has the insulation permanently reidentified to indicate its use as an ungrounded conductor by marking tape, painting, or other effective means at its termination and at each location where the conductor is visible and accessible. Identification shall encircle the insulation and shall be a color other than white, gray, or green.

While it does not specify red, the most common colors for hot wires in a residential load center are red and black and there is already a black wire.

>NO WHERE IN THE NEC DOES IT SPECIFIY THAT THE COLOR RED BE USED ON A CURRENT CARRYING CONDUCTOR
It is true that very few colors are specified in the code book. However, choosing a color other than red in that specific application can lead to being gently guided to 90.4 in the code book by the inspector. You'll find out about that once you finish studying the code book just to pass the test. It's a real world thing, not a sneaky code theory question.
Sometimes the AHJ wants purple to be the second phase for a 277/480 system because orange is also a high leg. If you decide to pick blue instead because there is "nothing in the codebook", the AHJ will happily remind you that you, while being technically right, are also wrong. Wrong enough to fail the inspection. Because the authority having jurisdiction for enforcement of theCodehas the responsibility for making interpretations of the rules, for deciding on the approval ofequipment and materials. And how would you, as an electrician, not know to use red.

this is flat out incorrect, but over here we just call them GFCI rather than RCD.
>solid core ----- they're more prone to breaking,
This isn't true. For one thing, it's a lot easier to break or accidentally nick/cut a strand in a stranded cable during stripping or terminating, which reduced its effective diameter and makes it less than the proper size. Also, IDK how much work hardening you expect to happen with solid core wires in a residential or light commercial setting, but it's simply a non-issue.

Your complaints are simply without merit and are entirely inane and without any relevance. These are non issues, and if you want to complain about USA wiring practices, you should at least pick a topic that is actually worth complaining about like the requirements for buggy AFCI protection, the buggy and insecure "smart" meters, the best effort/rule-of-thumb grounding electrode system rules, etc etc etc.

At the end of the day, the real issue is not hypothetical superiority of one path vs another. The question is: what are the failure rates or safety/damage incidence rates in this system vs another.

a gfci (american term for RCD) outlet can be installed in a way that protects the entire circuit it's installed on just like a gfci/rcd breaker. we use gfci outlets in places where a ground fault is more common (around water sources in homes) so you don't have to go to the breaker box to reset it, and often limit them to just the outlet where ground fault is common to avoid the annoyance of an entire circuit going down from a ground fault at the one outlet
I agree that gfci/rcd breakers are a generally more robust and overall safer solution but we also very commonly use gfci breakers as well

posts.com: I have a 50W COB LED that burned out/melted the lens and was blinking. Replaced the LED with a new one but it still just blinks. Is the driver damaged? Wrong voltage? do I need a resistor or something?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2545989
if its a constant current driver you need to make sure the specs are the same, if the driver is at the wrong voltage to drive its current it will cut off and reset. could be broken sure, but lots more to check before we are at that stage.
you might use a resistor for a low power led but extremely unlikely for a high power led, high power leds heat up which makes it difficult. anyway most resistors are 1/4w, 1/2w your power supply would need to be around 0.5-1% over voltage to not destroy the resistor at 50W.
most likely a constant current driver and your new cob is out of spec for it, need the current and voltage specs for driver, old led and new led to make a judgement.
there is a /sqtddtot/ thread for next time you have a question like this

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2545289
I'm sure Creo is, as is the case with everything CAD related, the most capable of the task, but the learning curve will likely be somewhat painful.

The difference between Inventor and Creo is that Creo doesn't even let you in the door, the UI is impossible to navigate, the rendering system is unstable, etc. However, under the hood, the tools do work. In the right hands, it can be an incredibly powerful tool, however, using it still sucks.

Inventor on the other hand, appears on the surface to be a competent piece of software. The UI is fantastic, things are where you think they would be, and on a surface level, it works well enough. However, the moment you ask it to do something even the slightest bit more complicated than "make a shape that is just a bunch of cubes welded together", it completely shits the bed in an unprecedented, unfathomably bizarre way, and everyone on the forums will be like "yeah that's a bug that was introduced in 2008 and Autodesk released a software patch that was supposed to fix it, but instead it just added another bug, which resulted in extruding a hole on the origin to cause your part to collapse into 2-dimensions. This is now a critical part of Inventor workflow, and you are stupid for not knowing this"

Fusion, SketchUp, etc. are toys in comparison, so they're not even worth comparing against. They're useful for small DIY projects, but if you're doing something as involved as designing a stamping die, those tools are well below your paygrade.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2544625
LOL, no it is not and they aren't "big".
Walls on perfectly solid foundations get surface cracks all the time from normal expansion/contraction of the materials used to construct and finish them, which usually don't expand/ contract at the same rates, which causes cracking when the weakest part gives way.
On a smooth troweled wall, the material used to do the final finish and thecpaintboverbit are almost always the weakest materials so any movement beneath them telegraphs through.
In this case the zigzag pattern corresponds to masonry block joints, which also happen to use mortar that is weaker than the surrounding block and can expand at different rates.
If you could stick your whole hand in there or it happened overnight it might point to foundation issues but even then catastrophic failure of that kind that requires action doesn't look like that and involves far more than just some orderly cracks you can't even slide a business card in.

For the OP: do yourself a favor and ditch regular drywall mud and use an elastomeric patching material designed to stretch slightly to accommodate minor movement like that...for cracks that small you can even use elastomeric caulk.
If you use regular mud you'll be doing it again in a year, tops.

So I'm in an 1892 tenament, basically. Exterior walls are brick and the interior sides are two-coat plaster laid right on the brick. (Interior walls are theee-coat horsehair on lathe. And you don't want to know about the wiring.)
Problem is, those exterior walls being brick weep.
Normally the brick dry themselves out in time. But it's been raining like fucking crazy and winter being winter, it's weeping into the interior sire plaster. That's causing the finish coat to crack and the paint to peel.
This happened several years ago the same way. And I "repaired" it by scraping, floating another finish coat, and repainting. Been hoping ever since.
As it looks like I'm going to have to do this again, Is there something I ought to really be doing here in 2023 to put in a proper vapor barrier?
Should I just go crazy and tear down to the brick and throw coats of polyurethane on it for that raw brick look?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2545001
1892 is a lot older than the older structures I've been involved in rehabbing and maintaining ( done a lot of restoration on 1920's-30's stuff) so I'm no expert and haven't done tons of older brick...but all that said, I'd recommend looking into silane/siloxane based sealers, they are water thin and deep penetrating, leave no film or coating to peel off, but resist water penetration like crazy while still being breathable. There's lot to know about them so do your research and maybe consult with some pros; they aren't cheap as liquid materials go but can save a ton of repair costs and are pretty easy to apply so they can pay for themselves quickly.

Here's a basic overview-
https://silanesiloxanesealer.com/sealer-uses/brick-water-repellent/

One product line- I haven't used it but Sika is a reputable brand, FWIW I'd pay the freight to get a pro grade material over a hardware store brand, if only for the technical assistance a weatherproofing supply house can give you-

https://usa.sika.com/en/construction/repair-protection/coatings-water-repellents/silane-siloxane-coatings.html

Note that besides the water thin stuff they have thicker emulsion and cream versions, a pro can help you choose the best option for your particular circumstance...older places like that often have quirks based on the specific materials used at that time or in that region, like mortar or brick made with raw materials high in some mineral or element that does something weird after 100 years. Sand (especially beach sand) that wasnt properly washed is a big one that can cause concrete and cement based products to need serious help down the road, Sika makes a lot of great products to help remediate stuff like that.
Good luck.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2543248
They aren't generally the best saws for straight line work and the ones with a sloppy arbor mechanism will always create problems...but regardless of the saw these things will help-

-Let the saw do the work, excess pressure on the blade easily drives it off track...also make sure the tooth count/set is adequate, too fine a blade invites overpressuring it
- Use a blade with a wide chord (front to back measurement), thin scroll blades want to deflect
- Make sure the teeth are oriented to cut on the upstroke, this pulls the blade straighter as it cuts rather than pushing against the friction ofvthe teeth biting in
- Use the orbital feature if equipped, it lessens forward pressure and makes a kerf better suited to keep the blade on track

As long as planet earth exists you have a home. You could get a solar panel kit with a battery bank, depending on your portable you could power a phone, tablet, or laptop. Check your local campsites to see if they have free land, big ones usually do on the off-season. If your campsite doesn't have public wifi, look into a 4g/5g router kit. Register for a P.O. box or ask a friend to have an address for work.

>>2530328
The secret is that those wood pilings are submerged all the time. Without any oxygen able to get to the wood they last perfectly well for decades.
Other examples are the pilings houses stand on in the Netherlands or those supporting the Speicherstadt in Hamburg Germany.

For wood pilings it is vital that they're submerged all the time. The oxygen starvation prevents or heavily delays the decomposition processes.

Best example is now in the Netherlands those same wood pilings. Due to the heavy dewatering of the low laying areas for pasture the soil itself drops down exposing the pilings themselves at the top causing them to rot right under the brick walls.

There's an old dude on Ambergris Caye who's the last remaining fisherman in the area permitted to harvest live conch from the reefs. Every day he goes out and gets a haul of conch, then putters his boat over to the same spot where he's been cleaning them for decades. He pops them out of their shells, and tosses all the shells overboard, to the point that the spot is a shallow area from the tens of thousands of accumulated conch shells.
He makes middling money from selling the meat to restaurants, but the wild thing is that he could set up a 20 sqft stall in San Pedro and sell these shells to tourists for $50-100 apiece, easily. Could probably make 10x his current income, even accounting for the retail space rent and the cost of hiring someone to staff it full-time, but he just throws the things away. My mom traded him a cold soda for a shell the size of her head.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2537916
A square will always give maximum floor space for any given total wall perimeter length.

Example: 16' wall length × 4 walls = 64 linear feet of wall...256 Sq ft of floor area.

Reduce two opposing walls to 10" and add the other 6" to the other two sides and you get a 10' × 22' rectangle ...and lose 36 Sq ft of floor area.

Split your 64' of perimeter wall up as 8' × 24' and you're down to 192 sq ft.

FWIW a dome creates maximum interior *volume* for any given amount of building envelope surface area, but using it all efficiently in a strictly residential context is tricky and you have to adapt to their quirks. They still work well in certain circumstances involving extreme weather conditions, and can be relatively quick and cheap to build.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2538015
>A square will always give maximum floor space for any given total wall perimeter length
False. This is a property of circles.

Given that:
perimeter = 2 * pi * r
area = pi * r * r
perimeter = 64 feet

Then:
r = 10.19 feet
area = 3.14 * 10.19 feet * 10.19 feet
area = 326 square feet

The rule is that the more sides you add to the polygon, the more efficient the structure (e.g., triangle < square < hexagon < octagon < ... < circle). But like you said, all the sides have to be of equal length to maximize the area.

>>2538272
>Heating and cooling is the most efficient in a cube
Heat is exchanged more easily the more surface area you have. A cube has more surface area per volume than a comparable sphere. Therefore a cube exchanges heat more easily, and is worse at insulation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2538272
>Rafter costs don't change much going fewer wider or more shorter

That is incorrect. Lumber comes in standard lengths, which means trusses are cheapest when using increments of standard sizes. In the US 16' is the longest standard length. Making 17' trusses requires more work and more waste material.
Common dimensions range from 32′ or 40′ in width with a fink (or standard) style truss. The truss itself can vary in width depending on the weight load and style of the building.

A truss can remain unsupported in the center for up to 80 feet. However, this size is likely extremely costly and impractical in residential construction. The most you’d likely see in a home is 40 feet.

There is no standard size as it greatly depends on the size of the house, but 32' is the most common.

>>2545461
>I have a property in France, about 7 acres, about 50 meter elevation with a water source and enough land to capture water and deviate it to where it needs to be
50 meters is the elevation drop from your water source to the outfall on your property? On only 7 acres? What's the flow rate?
A ram pump is useless unless you: (a) need to get water from a lower elevation to a moderately higher elevation; and (b) the water at the lower elevation has a relatively high flow rate (as the ram pump only elevates water proportionally to the water bypassed through the pump and is far from 100% efficient).
Pumping water from a ram pump to a higher elevation to produce head for hydroelectric generation is useless unless you have the world's largest ram pump and it cannot be hooked up directly to a turbine, it needs an outlet consistently at normal atmospheric pressure to function. You may use a ram pump to fill a pool and generate from it, but for typical sizes you would only be able to run the turbine for a few minutes every few days.
Same for collecting rainwater into a pool unless, again, you are taking up most of the 7 acres with a reservoir.
If you have high flow and low head / elevation drop you would be better off looking at a vortex turbine.

>>2542851
No, worm gears are used in all kinds of applications where you want to minimize the possibility of motion being reversed and the driven gear driving the drive gear...a worm drive will tend to lock in place when power is removed. They are common in casement window operators and all kinds of mechanical devices, what's less common about Crescent wrenches is that the worm gear drives a rack rather than a radial gear.
This differs from typical rack and pinion setups because the linear motion in those racks is at right angles to the pinion gear rotational axis, in a rack and worm gear the worm gear rotational axis is parallel to the racks linear motion as shown in picrel.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2543320
>wrench that is adequately sized won't round off a nut unless it spreads,
A straight wrench puts large amounts of force directly on the corner of fasteners. Its the main cause of damage and rounding off.

Pic related, all adjustable wrenches are straight cut, just like a straight cut socket.

All combination wrenches with a box end made in the last 30 years use a flanked box end.
This is why you are told to break fasteners free, and snug them up with the boxed end if at all possible. You pull the pressure further back from the corners.

Your adjustable wrench, and to a lesser extent your open end wrench rounds off like crazy.
Higher end wrenches have flanked open ends which fix the problem, but its kind of a waste, just use the box end.

>adequately sized won't round off a nut unless it spreads
Yes it will, but if it spreads, it makes the pressure on the corners exponentially worse and rounding that much more likely.
And ALL adjustable wrenches back off and move as you use them, compounding the problem. There is no "life hack" of "hold it with your thumb" or any other horse shit that keeps it from moving. Even >>2543029 dont work worth a fuck.
So yes, even though open end on combination wrenches round off, they do it far less frequently than an adjustable.

The people who laud adjustable wrenches are actual retards.

>>2543029
Yes, you are technically correct. But there are 2 caveats that don't make your statement true.
1. The bolt isn't perfectly flat
2. You are tightening the worm gear by hand, with no mechanical advantage.

And what does that mean in practice? It means the wrench won't tighten completely, meaning more force is going to go on the edges of the nut, which is going to start rounding the nut. If the nut is already partially rounded from warping as it gets tightened and loosened, or from manufacture tolerance. there can be enough of a gap that the metal gives, and you round it.

If the tightening mechanism had a external handle, so you can could get 10:1 or 20:1 or 30:1, it might be possible to tighten enough that you can get a flat surface to grip into.
But not with a worm gear tightened via your fingers.
Even then....
A socket already has 3 times the grip, but likely more due tolerance and angles. The wrench don't.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2546249
the grain is going horizontally across the top and sides. not end grain style. long pieces

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2546254
Good news then: you can get an extremely sturdy joint by just gluing a piece on with the same grain direction. You should stick to the same species of wood if you can as that will mean they move at roughly the same rate. If you want to give it a higher safety factor, once you've glued it on (clamp it really fucking tight) you can drill holes through it and hammer in a handful of dowels with glue so they penetrate 1-2 inches into the block. Even if the glue fails the dowels will compensate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2546257
I feel like I should elaborate: you will have to take your glue surface back to bare wood (ie. remove the finish) and you will also have to finish the piece you glue on. It's not particularly important to match the finish as I assume this is in a reasonably climate controlled area though for aesthetics sake you should. You just don't want it bare because depending on species it could move a lot.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2544489
This is the answer. An angle grinder is, in my opinion, very rarely the best tool for the job. When you use them for things they *are* the best tool for the job for (removing mill scale from steel with a flap disk, for example) they are relatively safe. Cutoff wheels are genuinely dangerous and I will go to great lengths to not use one. Get yourself a die grinder for small work and a proper set of saws for larger stuff. They are much cheaper than an ER visit.

Get a corded one with a paddle switch. The cord limits its reach, which is a safety feature. You shouldn't be using an angle grinder somewhere that you don't have power, because if something happens, you don't want to be unreachable. I have the Bosch GWS10, and it's fantastic.

And I'm sure I'll be called gay for my great level of caution, but I've personally seen enough brutal zip disk injuries for a lifetime. I one time watched a guy drop an angle grinder with one of those fucking "chainsaw" blades and stood in horror as it ran up his leg and into his crotch. He was in the hospital for a month. Don't fuck around, you only get one body.

>>2545623
>It's happened to me a few times

Sounds like excessive pressure. Quality discs like Pferd and SAIT (I buy boxes from the local welding supply or online) hold up very well. I let the disc float and maintain control, and importantly I rock it forward and backward in the plane of rotation to avoid binding like the industrial abrasive cutoff saw I used at my first job.

I prefer 6" grinders for the reach, easy control and edge speed, and modded the guards on my 4-1/2" cordless grinders to 6" by variously buying a 6" guard and removing the internal nubs (DeWalt) or cutting and welding (Makita, Milwaukee) to combine their mounts with 6" guard shells. Works great.

Don't wear gloves (generally, there are exceptions) when using stationary power tools where you manipulate the work piece or controls. Do wear gloves when using hand-held power tools where your hands are on the tool.

Angle grinders produce sparks, heat, and vibration, and they're high-speed low-torque tools. Gloves provide a favorable risk balance against the hazards they present.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2541913
I've had this issue before. The problem was that the blower motor had bushings that were open and completely exposed to the dusty air being sucked in with no way to add oil from outside the motor. The front bushing dried up and had enough play to cause the rotor to touch the stator which causes the grinding noise and shorts out the induction motor so it doesn't spin.

I doubt it's a bad capacitor, you spinning it by hand is what the capacitor does; gives it a kickstart to get it going.

I had to pull the blower out of the furnace, undo the grubscrew holding the impeller to the motor and then pull out the motor (this is a bitch to do since the motor shaft becomes rusted to the impeller). Then I took the motor apart which exposed the bushing packing which is a cotton like material and soaked it with 3 in 1 oil. I do this every year now to stay ahead of it.

First check if your motor has these plugs that let you oil from the outside.
https://youtu.be/UKoK_U_GKZI?t=59

But by the sounds of it if it's that far gone you probably need to open it up and clean it anyways.

I'd look at small amplifiers from SMSL or Topping or Fosi. You should be able to find something for $100 or less if you just want something small and relatively inexpensive.

Otherwise search craigslist or facebook for a used receiver for something cheaper. Pretty much any receiver will have a "line in" you can connect to the computer. Some will also have a digital connection if you'd prefer to run a digital signal to the amp ... it should sound a little better.
A receiver will be larger, but an old used one might be $20 or so, and that'd work fine.

Pic related is about as cheap as you're going to find if you want to buy something new and small.
It might sound like crap but it'll make sound.
I wouldn't buy it though ... I'd either spend more on something better, or find something used.

Here we discuss microcontrollers, SBCs and microcontroller accessories, such as Atmel mega and tiny AVRs (Arduinos), PICs, ARM boards such as blue/black pill STM32, ESP8266/32s, RP2040, Raspberry Pi, and others.

For general electronics questions (power supplies, level shifting, motor driving, etc.) please ask /ohm/.

>where can I find verified quality microcontrollers and other electronic sensors or parts
digikey.com
mouser.com
arrow.com
newark.com

>but that's too expensive
aliexpress.com (many parts here are fake, particularly specific parts out of stock in the above sites)
lcsc.com

>I need a part that does X and Y, with Z specifications. How can I find it?
use digikey or mouser's parametric part search. Then purchase from one of the sellers listed above.

>how do I get started with microcontrollers, where should I start?
There is no defined starting point, grab a book and start reading or buy an arduino off ebay/amazon and start messing around. There are a plethora of examples online to get started.

>resources:
https://github.com/kitspace/awesome-electronics

No, as far as I can see there aren't any technologies that let you print both a strong insulator and a good conductor at the same time, not to mention be heat-resistant enough to solder on.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2540641
Sounds like a boot loop of some sort. I'd guess something is dragging the 3.3V rail low enough that the regulator can barely keep up (e.g. shorted I/O, dying capacitor). I'd guess that it getting dimmer is the MCU itself trying to turn on, drawing the rail even lower, and turning off due to brown-out detection. That or it's always on but something inside it or its brown-out detector takes a second to kick in.

Does the regulator or any other component get hot? What regulator is it? Can you measure the input current? Post circuit if it's not trivial.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2540729
>a 18650 going into a AMS1117
Read the AMS1117's datasheet. It requires a typical dropout voltage of 1.1V, possibly up to 1.5V. So even a fully charged (4.2V) 18650 is out of spec, which is completely consistent with the symptoms you're seeing

You should go for a lower dropout regulator, like the HT7333 (only 0.09V dropout). It's also an option to use a discrete P-channel MOSFET (or PNP transistor if the dropout doesn't prove a problem) with a rail-to-rail op-amp to make your own regulator circuit.

>>2542476
Although I doubt this is the actual issue, is there a microSD card in your ESP32 module? I was having a somewhat similar error and if I remember correctly the issue was that the microSD card was fried. The ESP32 module worked fine when I removed or replaced the microSD card. I doubt this is the case though since if your code uses a microSD card then it would probably halt and not send the serial data that it's sending, and if it doesn't use it then chances are you wouldn't have one inside.

Alternatively, maybe it's a permission issue with your USB. If you're on linux you might have to use chmod to give yourself permission to use the USB device. On Windows or Mac maybe it would do it automatically. Again though if it's sending serial data through the serial monitor then I suspect that's not the issue either.

For a "fast" ADC like this, with one output pin for each digit, is it essentially a requirement to have dedicated hardware such as an FPGA to fetch the data and save it in a memory buffer?

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2543963

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2543938
Completely different ballpark. a RasPi has 500MB RAM minimum, while an ESP8266 has hundreds of kB. Go for something with an allwinner chip on it, look at that chip's prices on LCSC or digi-key to see what the chips (and dev-boards) cost for comparison.

>>2543963
150MS/s, 14-bit, but it outputs a parallel stream of data. So with direct IO register manipulation you could theoretically shuffle that data into memory with a 150MHz clock frequency. With a dual-core micro you should then be able to access that memory just as fast, maybe requiring only a single core if the data can be transferred via some sort of parallel DMA hardware, sans any processing. Multiply that clock by as many simple operations you need to do.

The video display bit might be possible with direct C or ASM programming atop an SBC, otherwise I suspect you'd need an FPGA. I'd try to outline the steps required to convert those numbers into packets for the display.

~$50
The Atomic Pi is a full-blown x86 PC that shits all over many other SBCs: https://www.amazon.com/DLI-APi-Atomic-Developers-Kit/dp/B08CGFM2B1
That's because it's not a SBC, they're surplus embedded computers originally intended for a robot that never hit the market, and some company bought their surplus of x86 boards and started selling them as "Atomic Pi" single-board computers.
They're old crap, but they're good, and for $50 it'll play Fallout 3 on medium settings at 1024x768.
~$36
The Makerbase Pi clone https://www.aliexpress.us/item/3256804231556479.html
It's trash next to a Pi4, and intended for 3D printer use.
~$35
Libre Le Potato: https://www.amazon.com/Libre-Computer-AML-S905X-CC-Potato-64-bit/dp/B074P6BNGZ
Another "hell no it's not as powerful as a Pi" but it's still a legitimate board at a fair-ish price with a fabulous name.
~$30
There are also plenty of folks who use Android set-top boxes, as many run the same Allwinner chips you find in plenty of Chinese SBCs (like much of the Orange Pi lineup).
Various H6 and H616 boards are fucked with depending on your needs.
This Allwinner H6 T95 Mini runs about $30: https://www.amazon.com/T95-Mini-TUREWELL-cortex-A53-Streaming/dp/B07SM8WTBT
You can install Inovata's Armbian on at and have at it, but with a lack of any GPIO.
~$25
Onion Omega2+, tiny, runs Linux, has an MT7688 MIPS processor so that's fun.
~$25
Orange Pi Zero 2, I shouldn't have to explain what this is.
~$20

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2545460
If you're designing a product, off-the-shelf SBCs are a terrible choice anyway.
Unless you're specifically targeting certain enthusiasts, like designing a Raspberry Pi accessory.
If you're designing a product based around an SBC though, don't fuck around with off-the-shelf crap unless you'll be making the entire volume yourself at home.
Reference designs for ARM based SBCs are freely available, and parts availability is excellent.
There are also companies out there who will produce custom made-to-spec SBCs specifically for use in commercial applications, like Anders Elec, who has board designs floating around in virtually every industry and every corner of the globe without any of the users knowing it, including some of the off-the-shelf SBCs from other companies.

This house was originally built as a one bed/bath plus a kitchen, built on piers. From what I can tell, they added a living area + bed/bath, but my guess is they knocked down the one side to build the addition, which has caused the original section to settle significantly. You can see that the wall between is buckling, assuming that the half settling half is pulling down on the wall.

Do I try to jack up the settled half and pour a foundation? Do I demo the one side or do I just tear down the whole thing? Total, the house is about 1,200 sq ft and obviously all the electric and water is routed through the original half. Building codes are non-existent in the area

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Climb under there jack it up use 4x4 posts cut to length setting on a concrete paver. Do it on every other joist. Take a whole day

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2546221
Honestly I think you need someone with experience/knowledge to do the asessment because you are making assumptions that may seem intuitive but can be way off.
Removing a wall alone wont make an entire structure settle, and where an addition is added at an existing wall without proper foundation reinforcement to carry the extra load it doesn't usually squeeze the building height so that the walls shorten and paneling bows out...it's more common for the upper wall and roof framing to stay more or less in place and the floors and their framing to sink and pull away leaving gaps along the floor/wall joint, opening horizontal seams and cracks in wallboard, etc. It's not like a giant is sitting on the roof flattening everything out.
Its not necessarily a terribly hard fix to level things out, retrofitting footings can be a bitch after thing are built but do-able...
Regardless, if you have settling issues, expansive soil, etc. and a house built in stages via additions, mixing foundation types is the last thing you want so if you beef anything up do it all the same or you'll be chasing after different settling rates and independent movements of original and added structure forever.

posts.com: Pic is my delta wall mounted kitchen faucet without the cover plate. This model isn't sold anymore. There are wall mounted kitchen faucets for sale but none (that I've seen) have a wall plate that covers the whole area like this one. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Don't think you'll necessarily find one that's plug and play but something like picrel might be a starting point

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2543732
Search on "wall mounted kitchen faucet". Lots of choices out there. The biggest problem is going to be the dimension between the hot and cold feeds and if that will fit an available new unit. It appears that you have some sort of tubing compression fittings there. You might be able to remove that and fit an NPT fitting. Can't tell until the old one is off the wall.

Best thing to do is to find a local plumbing fitting supply place ahead of time with counter people that know their shit. So when you run in for one last part you need, you don't have to search all over town.

When that initial covid toilet paper thing happened, I got some Brondell bidet off Amazon. It was about $30 then. It's the bolt on kind, where you take the seat off to install it.
Works pretty well, I like it. Only two settings: spray your ass, and self-clean. That was more important to me than multiple nozzles, multiple water input/temp control, etc.

There's a "splatter shield" in front of the nozzle, and the nozzle only extends when you're using it. Uses the line pressure to extend, when you cut the water a return spring pulls it back up. The self-flush/clean does a good job, it's been low-maintenance.

Didn't use the toilet supply line, I ran off the sink's hot water. So there will be an initial room temp spray, then HOT lol. I did get toilet seat bump stops that are slightly taller (maybe 1/4"?) so I don't stress the seat when I'm sitting on it.

If the city water is turned off (depressurized) then the poop water could be siphoned back into the city water system, leading to contamination. Certain weird cases such as fire hydrant use can also cause negative pressure in the pipes in your home.
You'll find that a lot of the codes, including the electrical and building codes, have to do with addressing edge cases where several unusual fault states are present at the same time.
>>2531683
I'm not that anon, but there are several code sections like Universal Plumbing Code section 603 which talk about back flow preventers. IDK if it's applicable to bidet hoses, but its an oversight if they haven't addressed it specifically in the code. The exact same mechanism of action that could lead to contamination from a pull down sprayer in a commercial sink or a garden hose could be found in these bidet hoses.

posts.com:
2 Professional solutions that are probably not what OP is looking for because they are expensive:
-Get a "tap" for bathing tubes or showers next to your toilet and connect it with a very small shower head (some hundred bucks for the tap, some hundreds for the work and pipes, tiles and shit need to be removed and made new)
-Get a toilet with integrated ass-shower (several thousand bucks)

My /diy/-advice: Get 2 multi-angle-valves where your wash basin is. It is usually near the toilet. The Kinda valves that you put an additional outlet for washing machines. Then do some /diy/ plumbing (you could even use a garden hose) from the 2 valves down and pull them next to your toilet. Then connect them with 2 1/2" "connector panels" (one for warm, one for cold) that you fix on the wall (you can use the tile joint so you don't have to drill into the tiles. Enclose the /diy/ piping with cheap drywall shit and put picture related on the connector panels.

That would be the /diy/ way of making your own ass shower.

If your landlord don't like it you can tear it apart and none of the tiles will be damaged. If the piping leaks you can just turn it off at the angle valves.

>>2545197
get a second roof over it, people who live in RV trailers and shipping containers will tell you what a difference it makes not to have direct sunlight on your roof surface. If there are reasons that's not possible, the next best solution is an insulated air gap at the ceiling. like, get some wood-concrete glue, glue some lumber across the bottom of the roof then attach bubble foil or foam board across it. This will leave an air pocket that will trap the radiant heat. I've seen this used in old metal buildings that didn't have any insulation at all and it made a huge difference in minimizing summer time heat

>didn't put a layer of insulation between concrete pours

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Roof-mounted polyisocyanurate insulation board. R-3 per inch. Your problem is "easy". Chances are the old roof would need to come off in order to put down the insulation board because it needs to be epoxy applied to the concrete deck. There are mechanical fasteners made for this, but you're taking a huge risk of the concrete is old and shitty (i.e. breaking big chunks off driving fasteners through it). You can loose lay it with insulation board and membrane, but you would need ballast in the form of gravel or pavers to hold the fucker down. Local code might prohibit this as well if you live in a very high wind zone or hurricane zone.
>Oh, it's solid concrete
If you have a water proofing system like Tectum as the base, epoxy down polyiso, fully adhered membrane over the top. This is not a DIY application unless you want to spend 800 bucks on a two part epoxy spray backpack rig.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2543909
Some disappointing updates which is why I didn't post them. I figured nobody else cared and I'm not sure if I'll be able to finish the project before the thread loses momentum. I brought the wheel out to test in the car and when attaching it up to my intended power source the car triggers the horn. I have an electrical diagnostic manual for my car so I referenced the horn circuit and it turns out it powers the horn when the circuit is closed (kind of obvious in hindsight). The doubly disappointing news is my other constant 12v power, which runs to the cruise control buttons, also triggers the horn when grounded because it shares the same inputs. I asked an electrical engineering friend if there was any way around it with the current layout and the only thing he could come up with was borrowing a signal wire from the cruise control circuit and redirecting it through a raspberry pi. From there I considered tearing down my clockspring and replacing the ribbon inside with one that contains more wires. I was wondering about amperage as well, so I googled how much amperage a clockspring could handle and happened upon this thread from someone asking the same question for the same application as mine: http://www.saturnfans.com/forums/showthread.php?t=267981

In any case, my plan now is to salvage the clockspring from a newer car with more leads as well as from another identical Honda as mine and frankenstein the two together. Probably going to take a trip to a scrap yard sometime this week.
>inb4 but muh splicing airbag wires
suck my dick I'm going to have warm hands if it kills me

To make all matters worse, my DC power supply came in DOA. didn't output any power unless I beat it, then it spiked and slowly dropped voltage from like 15 to 0. I did power the wheel via a car battery to confirm it works, however, and I'm pretty happy with my layout (although I'd put the wires further apart/more on the inside if I did it again)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
A good welder with dexterity and expert knowledge will be able to do gas- and liquid tight welds that withstand alot of pressure and won't even corrode, but somebody who doesn't know what he's doing will ruin any bloody workpiece no matter the machine and material he's using.

So OP, you should learn about welding - practical and theoretical - then you won't need to worry about shit like "chinese welding rod".
If you wanna learn how to weld steel on a budget just use hanger wire and an oxy torch.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
For many people and projects, they are a poor source of lumber.
However, they are not useless.

The GOOD - They are often free for the taking and they are often hardwoods

The BAD –
Their size limits their usefulness.
They are often aged or damaged.
They are more awkward to haul home than a stack of boards.
They require disassembly.
They do not all use the same sized boards, you have to find matching pallets to get a bunch of boards that are all the same dimensions.
They sometimes are treated with Methyl Bromide, which is a health risk.
They have nail holes, often quite noticeable.
Sometimes they have unknown substances spilled on them from leaks.
It is a hassle to make them not look like pallet wood.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Pallets are stamped, but not on every board.
Only some pallets have risky chemicals, many are plain wood.

Pallets stamped HT are heat treated and safe to burn.
Pallets marked MB contain Methyl Bromide and should NOT be burned.

>Methyl bromide is a fumigant used to control pests in agriculture and shipping. Methyl bromide also depletes the ozone layer. Therefore, along with other countries, the United States has phased out production and consumption of methyl bromide with important exceptions for critical uses as well as quarantine and pre-shipment.
https://www.epa.gov/ods-phaseout/methyl-bromide

Is there a safe way to get these carcinogens out/off of the wood? Not to my knowledge.

Easy rule of thumb if they are MB or you don’t know for sure.

Don't Burn Them!
Keep the sawdust out of your lungs and off of your skin. This applies to all sawdust, actually.
Don't make cutting boards or other things that touch food.
Paint will seal them if you are still worried about excessive contact.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Using pallets intact has some applications, especially if you can find them the same size. I have seen furniture, animal pens. and greenhouses made from them. (The furniture is usually pretty ugly.)

MB-treated boards make decent outdoor planter boxes and other rustic things like shelves for your shipping container shed to store imitation crab meat.

Taking it apart isn't hard if you have the right tools.

If you are going to salvage a whole bunch of pallets, consider getting a specialized prybar. I would prefer to get one locally, so I could try it out to see if it is worthwhile, then be able to return it easily if it is crap.
https://www.1001pallets.com/top-7-best-pallet-buster-pallet-breaker-reviews/

https://www.99pallets.com/pallet-projects/diy-storage-shed-from-pallets/

This is unlikely to become a Sticky, so please help it stay on the board by posting pics of your projects and links to pallet idea websites that might inspire others.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Pallet Parts and Terminology

Annular Ring Nails (also called Ring Shank) – These are one of the most common types of fasteners used in pallet design. In essence, it is a nail with circular ring threads on the shank.

Banding Groove – Dunnage with a groove cut into the length of the lumber. It is used to protect unit loads from damage when banding is tightened down to secure a load onto a pallet.

Blocks – A square or rectangular piece of wood that is placed between the pallet decks or beneath the top deck. Some blocks can even be cylindrical. Generally, blocks are located at each corner of a pallet, centered on each of the four sides, and in the middle of each pallet. Placement is crucial to ensure block pallet strength.

Block Pallet – A type of pallet that uses blocks to form its base instead of stringers.

Bottom Deck – The deck boards on the bottom of a pallet that are sitting on the ground or floor.

Butted Deck Board – The name given to an inner deck board that is attached to an adjacent deck board during assembly to help strengthen it. These are often used when recycling pallets and pallet parts.

CAD – Stands for Computer Aided Design and helps pallet designers design packaging solutions.

Chamfered Deck Boards – Deck boards with the edges beveled. They are usually only beveled on one or two faces, and allow pallet jack wheels to enter the pallet more easily.

Collar – A wooden container or bin that turns a pallet into a box.

Container Bin Pallet – This is basically a crate, box, container, or four-sided structure mounted on a pallet base.

Deck – The boards or panels that make up the top or bottom surface of a pallet.

Deck Board – The component boards or panels that make up a deck.

Deck Board Spacing – The distance between deck boards on a deck.

Deck Board Span – The distance between the deck board supports. Could refer to the distance between stringers or blocks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Deck Mat – The assembled deck boards and stringers that make up the deck of a block pallet.

Deflection – The amount of bending or deformation in a pallet under load. Could refer to the whole pallet or a specific pallet part.

Double Face Pallet – A pallet built with both top and bottom decks.

Economic Life (of a pallet) – The number of trips a pallet is expected to make in its serviceable lifetime, provided that it remains properly repaired.

EURO Pallet – Block pallets built to European Pallet Association specifications. They usually have a branded logo on them.

Fastener – A component used to join pallet parts together, such as nails, screws, bolts, or staples.

Flush Pallet – A pallet where the deck boards are even or flush, with the stringers or blocks along the sides of the pallet.

Fork Entry – The opening between decks and beneath the top deck of a pallet where forklift forks can be inserted to lift the pallet and load. Sometimes stringers will have notches in them to allow for fork entry.

Four-Way Block Pallet – A block pallet that has openings on all four sides of the pallet to admit pallet jack entry.

Four-Way Stringer Pallet – A stringer pallet that has notches cut in the stringers to allow for pallet jack entry.

GMA or Grocery Manufacturers of America – Thee GMA has its own specific pallet requirements for its standard pallets.

Hardwood – The type of wood that comes from deciduous trees. Generally, these are the trees with leaves instead of needles, but there are exceptions. Although called hardwood, that doesn’t necessarily mean that it’s hard or dense. It depends on the species of tree the wood comes from.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Inner Deck Board – Any deck board that is positioned between the end deck boards.

Joint – The point at which the components of a pallet intersect or connect. They are often identified as the end joint, center joint, and corner joint.

Length – In general, this is the first dimension given to describe a pallet and refers to the stringer or stringer board length. For example, a standard 48” x 40” pallet length is 48”, and is also the length of the pallet’s stringer.

Line Load – When the weight of a unit load is concentrated in a narrow area across the full length or width of a pallet.

Load Bearing Surface – The area of a pallet in contact with and supporting the weight of the unit load.

Multiple Use Pallet – A pallet designed to be used for several trips with different unit loads.

Non-Reversible Pallet – Describes a pallet where the bottom deck boards are configured differently from the top deck boards.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Notch – A cutout in the wood of a pallet part. It could refer to something like the notch in banding groove, or the notch in a notched stringer.

Notched Stringer – On a pallet, this is a stringer that has notches cut out of it to allow entry for forklift tines. The notch is usually ½” to 1” in depth and 9” long, depending on the size of the pallet.

Opening Height – This refers to the vertical distance between decks on a pallet. It’s measured from the floor to the top of the stringer notch, or from the floor to the underside of the top deck.

Overhang – The distance that the pallet deck extends past the outer edge of the stringer or stringer board. It’s also called a wing or lip. Overhang can also refer to the distance that a unit load extends beyond the pallet deck.

Pallet Life – The length of time that a pallet remains useful. It’s usually expressed in the number of one-way trips that the pallet is expected to make or in units of time.

Panel Deck Pallet – A pallet constructed with some type of paneling product (OSB, composite, etc.) for the top deck.

PDS – Stands for Pallet Design System and is a computer aided design program that helps engineers to design pallets to safely carry a load and maximize the supply chain.

Recycled Pallet – A previously used pallet that is recycled and has been repaired for reuse with replacement pallet parts as needed. It’s also referred to as a refurbished or reconditioned pallet.

Remanufactured Pallet – A pallet that’s been built from reclaimed pallet parts. Sometimes they are also built from a combination of new and reclaimed pallet parts.

Skid – A pallet with no bottom deck that rests on the stringers. It’s a little like a sled on rails.

Slave Pallet – A support base for a palletized load in rack-storage facilities or production systems.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Softwood – Softwood comes from evergreen trees. Generally, they have needles instead of leaves, but there are exceptions. The term softwood does not necessarily mean that the wood is a soft wood.

Solid Deck Pallet – Refers to a pallet that is constructed with no spacing between deck boards.

Span – The distance between block supports, stringer boards, or stringers.

Stevedore Pallet – Designed for seaport shipping docks, this pallet is designed with heavy-duty, double-wings.

Strapping – Flat, thin bands that are used to secure a load to a pallet. Often used with banding groove.

Strap Slot (also called a Banding Notch) – The notch or cutout on the bottom edge of the top deck board or the top edge of a stringer. It allows for strapping or banding to tie down a unit load.

Stringer – A solid or notched piece of lumber that is used to support the deck components on a pallet. Stringers run perpendicular to the deck components and there is usually one on each side of the pallet and one in the center.

Stringer Board – Refers to the solid boards that extend the full length of a block pallet and run perpendicular to the deck boards. Stringer boards are placed between the deck and the blocks.

SYP – Stands for Southern Yellow Pine, and it’s the wood most often used in wood protective packaging.

Take-It-Or-Leave-It Pallet – Refers to a pallet with fixed cleats on the top deck that provide a location for forklift tines to get under the unit load and lift the load off of the pallet.

Top Cap – A panel that is placed on top of unit load to protect it from strapping.

Two-Way Entry Pallet – A stringer pallet that does not have any notched stringers. Forklift tines can only enter the pallet on the ends.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Unit Load – The palletized goods sitting on a pallet.

Wing Pallet – A pallet with the top and bottom deck boards extending past the edge of the stringers. Can also be a double-wing pallet if both sides extend past the edge of the stringers. Wing pallets can be single wing or double wing.

posts.com:
Hold a level against the studs to figure out which is out of plumb. Pull or sawzall the nails out of all three studs at the bottom and whack them with a hammer until they're where you want them. Check plumb again and refasten the bottoms.

Next time, use a laser level to mark where the tops of your studs need to go with a pencil (on top of the laser line.) Fine tune your rough door opening with the level.

posts.com:
>>2537245
>a new material.

Epoxy manufacture began in the 1940s and its been used to stabilize and homogenize loose/ brittle materials like raw wood slabs and porous stone that could then be used for table tops since the 1950s.

That's also about the time that George Nakashima developed his signature style of live edge furniture that highlighted what would traditionally be seen as inferior lumber and didn't attempt to hide the methods used to keep those pieces intact.
Absolutely none of this is new, but neither is it some sacreligious affront to woodworking. The original point of using epoxy this way was functional and an act of conservation; the more you do it for its own sake the more it just becomes trendy kitsch.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2540997
>Epoxy sets into a plastic that deforms at low temperatures like most plastics.
Totally depends on the formulation and especially the temperature it was cured at, epoxies are regularly used in aerospace applications that require high rigidity.
That usually involves autoclaving during cure, but even non-autoclaved epoxies cure at higher than room temperature because the cure is exothermic, especially when it's in a mass of the type seen in one of those table pours. Epoxy pours that deep develop intense heat and once cured they won't lose rigidity due to heat unless they are taken past that cure temp.

And then just don't zap yourself. Turn the thing on from at least 10' away and don't step away from the switch without turning it off first and there's very little that can go wrong if you actually follow that rule even if you use kill you dead level output.
Aside from that there's standard high voltage safety practices like only using your right hand to not complete a circuit through your heart, insulated boots etc, but you should really just never be in a position where they would matter anyway.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Let me give you a tip anon. Instead of trying to set up "gate" style sensors that are activated as the projectile proceeds down the barrel, put an LED + photodiode at the back of the barrel (where the bolt would be in a normal firearm) and use the quantity of reflected light as a proxy for the position of the projectile. Naturally, the light level will start off very bright (since the back of the projectile is directly in front of the LED) and fall off as it is fired. If you calibrate this properly, I think you can get the position data you need. You can even crank up the LED power as the projectile gets farther away in order to increase the signal to noise (as long as you adjust your calculations to compensate for the increasing LED intensity).

> t. spent a lot of time building brushless linear motors and thinking about coil-based accelerators

How close are you to actually buy? Have you talked to a banker? One of the things that surprised me was how much closing costs are, expect another like 3%-5% of the purchase price in closing costs on top of what you want to put down.

Talk to a banker, get your preapproval letter. Then you will get an interest rate locked in for like 90days minumum which is sort of important as interest rates keep going up to fight Bidenflation. Pretty sure rates went up like 1.5% between my preapproval and closing when I bought this place last year.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Be seriously wary of anything built in the last two decades if it's in a neighborhood where everything was done by a single builder. In every example I've seen, they cheaped their way through every house in terms of both labor and materials. In some cases they skimped out on necessary things like proper flashing at roof edges which will inevitably lead to super expensive repairs. Not that builders in the past were any better, but the problems have had time to come to light.

Keep an eye out of work done by previous homeowners. Some people think they can /diy/ major structural changes without having a clue. I looked at a place where some numbnuts had removed a load bearing column to open up a living room, and there were cracks on adjacent walls where the place was starting to cave.

Inspectors are sort of a necessary evil. Some are bullshit, but I was saved from a money pit by one once so they have their place. Get your own and not one associated with your lender or realtor. General inspectors won't check certain systems in depth, so if you look at a property with anything like EIFS stucco, septic, or well water get a separate inspection for those.

Use Google street view to get an idea of what an area looks like if you don't already know. If you see derelicts or trash everywhere, don't waste your time looking at the house.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You are going to get a lot of contradictory information. For example, the thing about trees. changes in water, vegitation near your foundation - they all fuck things up. But not too much you can do about it. First time home buyer. been here 10 years now, and I'll tell you where our surprises were.

-Got a separate inspector for the AC. He found a significant issue - there was a 5 ton unit, but the house was ducted for a 4 ton. It was overworking the unit. Luckily the unit lasted another 7 years, but it was a good bargaining point. When we put in new unit had to pay an extra $300 for some duct changes.

-visit house at night on a weekend. Just chill in your car for an hour or more. It seems creepy, but you are gonna be sleeping there for the next 10 years. Did you know kids drag race on the access road? That you can hear the traffic from the freeway quite clearly at night?

-don't buy nicest house on your block. We fell for this. it didn't start that way, but as we fixed up the house, landscape, etc... you realize that there are some shitty houses around, epecially rentals, leave trash out blah blah blah. These places bring down your value and you can't do shit about it. funfact: last year with housing prices going crazy, 2 of the 10 houses on our cul de sac, including the one next to ours, were sold to out of town AirBnB faggots. Constant groups of strangers as neighbors now. I fucking hate it. They won't even repair the fence between us that has rotted apart, and won't split costs with us to do it.

-House is "just settling". look at foundations of other houses around you... are they all cracked? knock on some doors and say you are interested in moving in - have they had to do any foundation repair? Turns out everyone on our cul-de-sac has, because of the type of soil we have. That was $15,000 I wasn't expecting!

cont

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2545776
That "gizmo" in your picture is the hot surface ignitor (HSI) and it uses electricity to ignite the gas---- there's no pilot light on these kinds of models (with rare exception)

There is a solenoid valve in your second pic that controls the flow of gas to the oven burner. Normally you turn on the selector switch which first sends power to the HSI, giving it time to warm up, then finally it sends power to the solenoid and turns on the gas to ignite the burner and heat up the oven. It then turns the gas on and off in order to regulate the temperature according to feedback from a little sensor.

Try turning on the oven and then see if the HSI gets hot. If not, then check to see if it is receiving voltage.... Also, be careful if you remove it because they are Extremely fragile and easy to shatter.

A bad HSI is one of the most common points of failure on a gas oven and in a conventional gas furnace as well

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2545774
>how do you make a decent cross on a part?

Use a guide like machinist square, straight edge etc. I don't use blue dye, I copy the pros who use thick Sharpies (red or blue) as machinist dye because unlike liquid dyes they don't chip.

Another method is set your digital or vernier caliper to desired distance from the edge then lock the tension screw and scribe using that. Some autspergies worry about wearing the tips of the caliper jaws but if you actually managed to do that by then you paid for MANY calipers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Years ago, a hurricane knocked down every power line in sight, and my power was still off after 5 days. I had work, though, so on day five I'm coming home and see lights on all over the place, and I'm pissed because I know mine will still be off. It's raining, and you can hear thunder, so no way they're doing anything at the moment. I come around a curve and see three trucks with the booms up, working in the rain with lighting in the area. Later on, I decide that if we ever have another disaster I'll go around and see if I can do any favors for a crew.

Fast forward to the ice storm of the century, and again it's about day five of freezing weather with no power, and I'm driving to the store and I see guys huddled in the cab of their truck. "Can I get you anything, sausage biscuit, or what." One guy holds up a BoJangles box like he's sick of biscuits, and then another guy says he could use a drink because he's about to dry out since they're restricted to their hotel at night. It's about dark, and they say they'll be there for another half hour or so (this is right next to our neighborhood), so I go get a case of cold beer and some Jack Daniel's and some vodka. I come back and they are there, but they caution me to not show it since an asshole in the next truck will report them, so we stow it in a box and after a bit more work they leave.

About 15 minutes later they're back, and they take an hour or so in darkness to get our power back on.

posts.com:
>>2540324
I've always lived with art, made art, collected art and decorative objects.
They don't have to have any deep intrinsic meaning and sometimes what value they do have in that sense develops in the context of living with them for years, in different places, with different people, etc. Odd stuff can be the catalyst for all kinds of interesting conversations and as a kind of shorthand message sent to visitors; I have valuable art and also kitschy junk that grounds me to older relatives and their homes that had those same items, where I grew up and learned to appreciate them.

Bottom line is that decor thats there because its fun or pleasant to be around is a luxury that can be as small or large as you want it to be, and luxury is the difference between subsisting in a purely utilitarian existence, and living a life.
If people want to do the former that's fine, but those people NEED to convince themselves that they are superior. far more than people who enjoy small luxuries and non necessary aesthetic pleasures "need them to be happy", which is the cope that the ascetics like to tell themselves.

>>2540324
Basic philosophy? Avoid symmetry, avoid obvious themes, few larger pieces instead of smaller stuff, and no double-duty - using an ornate box as a stand, for example. Fewer is better, it focuses the attention, but no fewer than 3 or 4 points of interest in any single room.

Advice? If something catches your eye immediately walking into a shop or yard sale, buy it. I've never regretted an impulse art purchase.

Also, don't underestimate photos. It's out of fashion to actually print out your pics & hang them on the wall, but it's cheap & if you hang photos that are meaningful, you'll actually look at them when you walk by. Once you stop noticing them, they can be replaced easily.

If you outright copy something you've seen somewhere else, you probably won't like it long term. OP's photo looks like a diorama at a Ripley's museum. It'll feel like wasted space almost immediately.

>>2543761
If you make appropriate wooden cribbing you can jack the vehicle, pl place cribbing, lower it onto cribbing, then place jack on adjacent cribbing, raise and add cribbing or my favorite stable suppor, old alloy rims with a wood on top (they don't tip even in sand).

It's worth having cribbing for safety too as it's more stable than stands. First responders have used cribbing for a very long time.

I wrench often, work on machinery etc so I collect pressure treated 4x4, 6x6 and a 2x4 now and then for cribbing. I empty my drained oil into pails then soak the cribbing for a few days, remove and leave outdoors where I store it. That prevents rot for many years.

posts.com:
>>2539954
That's a boost converter, so when it's turned off there will still be a nonzero voltage across the LEDs. If instead of connecting the LED negative line to ground you connect it to the positive leg of the PSU/battery, you end up with some sort of inverting topology. Pic related.
If you do go for a 3V coin cell, you likely won't need any boosting at all if you can go for parallel LEDs, though it depends somewhat on LED wavelength.

As for making the most out of battery life, consider the posts from last thread about flashing an LED to keep some phosphor glowing. Read: >>2538168 and the replies to it.

posts.com: Need advice quick, can I use jewlery solder for wiring? Can't find anything online about doing that, just about pipe solder vs electrical.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2540029
I suspect that jewellery solder is the same as plumbing solder, a strong lead-free mix that needs to be soldered with a gas torch. If there are lower temperature ones that can be melted with an electric iron then go ahead, but as far as I know all electrical soldering alloys aren't too strong. Doubly so for lead-free stuff.

There won't be any electrical issues if that's what you're wondering. The only potential problems will be overheating of the surrounding components, or chemical damage due to a more active flux.

Is it just a simple as hooking it up to an oscilloscope for that purpose? I know it should produce a variable voltage even if it's not completely linear to the actual light hitting the sensor.
Pic related is what the actual sensor is

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2540115
Yeah, though a DC-blocking filter followed by a true RMS AC measurement might be more immediately useful. Assuming TRMS is what's intrinsically useful when it comes to light ripple. Just measuring frequency and peak-to-trough amplitude would be really easy, though if you're getting really sharp spikes it wouldn't necessarily be indicative of human perception. Maybe a low-pass filter could try to mimic human light perception.

If the sensor is just a raw photodiode, you'll want a constant-current source or resistor on it, and to measure the resultant voltage. The size of resistor or current source will determine the effective sensitivity and saturation level of the sensor.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2540155
The datasheet is a decent place to look, but existing circuits are a good idea also. Here's the schematic for the ESP-WROOM-32 module, and you can find the dev-board schematic that the ESP itself goes onto also. The dev-board has the USB-UART IC, a linreg, more bypass caps, reset and boot buttons, and a couple of transistors so the DTR and RTS signals going through the UART automatically put it in programming mode. Depending on how you plan on programming it those may or may not be handy.

After that I'd look at each part and cross-reference it to the datasheet. Like what the reset and boot buttons do, how much current the LDO needs to handle, what frequency oscillator you want, etc. Bypass capacitance is something you could probably ignore, but for good practice I'd read through that anyhow.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2540174
>What do you mean by flash IC?
Read the datasheet's section on memory, there's no internal program memory / flash. The chip requires a sufficiently fast external SPI flash memory IC to put programs on, as pictured here >>2540165 as U3. That flash IC is included under the metal can of an ESP-WROOM-32 module. The same applies to the ESP8266 and the RP2040.

>How challenging would that be if I just stick every component as close to the mcu as possible?
It's more about the antenna and getting the impedance matching. If you just copy the PCB design of a WROOM-32's antenna section you'll be fine, there may well be a section in the datasheet or in an Espressif appnote if you want to go more in-depth. At 2.4GHz the wavelength is 12cm, so the distance at which transmission line effects begin counting is about a tenth of that, or 1.2cm. If you cram things smaller than that it shouldn't really matter, though I'd consider using KiCAD's microwave toolkit anyhow, and following any given guidelines. Assuming you even need the RF capabilities in the first place.

>>2540189
You need single millivolt precision? Then I'd find a voltage reference capable of that (tight tolerances, low drift, and low tempco), an op-amp with sufficiently low input offset voltage, and a multiturn potentiometer and/or a cascade of pots of different sizes for finer and coarser control. Use the trimpot as a divider after the voltage reference, and buffer it with the op-amp. And I guess add a sufficiently accurate voltage readout I guess, I'd either just plonk a good DMM on it when you adjust it, or directly use that reference plus a decent ADC and an MCU to drive a display. I wouldn't trust alibay panel meters, though if you only care about relative error they may be acceptable.

In certain guitar amps you find valve pre amps with a so called shared cathode configuration. Basically two triode halves "share" their cathode resistor and cathode bypass cap (pic related left) The signal gets amplified by each half (in parallel) and the there is a slight difference in how they signals get filtered. One half has capacitors on the pots and mixer resistor so that the signal has way more treble at any time. The other half does not.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2540287
>But with such a shared cathode setup?
It probably has something to do with distortion. For small signals there shouldn't be any difference in operation as superposition principle applies (confirmed by your frequency response simulation). But once you start having large excursions tubes will start influencing one another because they share current path. If you want to simulate this you can't use AC simulation in spice because it will automatically linearize circuit and won't use large signal tube models. You need to do transient simulation and then compare FFT results.

posts.com:
>>2540221
>the only voltage reference I can supply is a shitty 5V output
No I'm saying you need to find a voltage reference IC/diode/whatever to put in your circuit. The typical TL431 has way too high drift and such to work, but it's just a matter of finding one that does work. Somewhat sensible values would be
> smaller than ±0.05% tolerance
> smaller than 25ppm/C tempco
For 0.5mV accuracy at 1V. If you need more or less than 1V output, you can scale those values appropriately. This one here is decent looking:
https://www.ti.com/lit/ds/symlink/ref35.pdf
And costs $5.50 each.
If you want to go to 0.01% tolerance and 5ppm/C tempco then you start running into trouble.

Personally I'd make something good to 3 digits of precision, since chances are you won't need any more than that. Consider if you really need both precision and accuracy.

>>2540308
Just go on a switching IC manufacturer's website and follow the instructions. Chances are they have online interactive tools and appnotes that help you select an appropriate transformer.

If you go for something variable frequency then you can basically use whatever transformer you want (flyback converters still need an internal air-gap, consider a forward converter instead). Personally I'd just power up a TL494 with a zener and go to town. A FET gate driver may be nice too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2540999
Analog multipliers are neat, but they're complex/expensive and don't allow for calculating other things like phase offset and sine quality. You'll need an anti-aliasing filter before the ADC anyhow, so if you end up having to sample on A then B then A etc. with 1ms between each sample, then you'll have an effective nyquist frequency of 500Hz, and would design the filter accordingly. Personally I'd go for a solution that lets you sample with at least a 5kHz nyquist frequency, as it gives you room for filter rolloff. An ADC with built-in filtering (like many delta-sigma ADCs tend to have) may be handy, and common audio ADCs are stereo anyhow, so might be a good choice if you can handle the bitrate and the I2S. An ESP32 would be able to do it easily.

>In the schematic, the collector of the transistor is connected to the supply voltage of 5V, and the emitter is connected to the ground with a 100 Ohms resistor. In the module, a set of 5 conducting plates are connected with the vcc in series with a 100 Ohms resistor and the other 5 sets are connected to the base of the NPN transistor. Now when the water touches these conducting palates, currents start flowing from the 5V supply to the base of the transistor, and the transistor turns on. The more submerged the sensor is, the more output voltage it will generate.

There will always be offset voltage by nature of how the multimeter works.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2542677
If you take the LMV358 RRIO op-amp as an example, the maximum input voltage is just 5.5V, not something like "Vcc+0.7". But when you look at the functional block diagram you can see that there are diodes from the inputs to the inputs to the power rails. So that ~1.6V would end up going into its power supply, which I assume is undesired. If you can find an op-amp without input protection diodes though it should work, as the PMOS input topology should be intrinsically tolerant to voltages above a supply rail. The same should apply to a CMOS op-amp I think, but they're probably also more likely to have input protection diodes for ESD reasons.

>>2542840
Best to have a series of decent ones. I say at least these three categories:
>general purpose - cheap like LM358
>audio - a JFET op-amp like TL072 or OPA2134
>RRIO if you do LV digital projects - something like an LMV358
Ground sensing op-amps (LM358 included) are really handy for current sensing purposes, though that usually overlaps with RRIO op-amps. Watch EEVblog's video on jellybean op-amps for more. Get general purpose and maybe RRIO comparators too.
Then maybe you plan on doing stuff that needs a really low input offset voltage, or really low quiescent current, or low noise, or can handle really high frequencies. At which point you'll need to look for more special-purpose op-amps.

>>2542856
USB data lines are at 3.3V anyhow. You'd just connect the data lines directly (maybe through resistors, maybe with TVS diodes, read the datasheet). If you also want to power it off USB, then use a 5V to 3.3V regulator from the USB's 5V power rail, not forgetting the filter caps.

As for whether they can be programmed directly through USB (i.e. without UART or JTAG), a quick look suggested it might be possible. But the pictures of ESP32 C3 dev-boards I can see seem to have two USB ports, one for direct connection to use as a keyb controller or whatever, and the other probably connected to a UART IC for programming.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2542889
I suspect he was joking

>>2542895
>is the RTC required for the operation of the esp32
No. It's used by the watchdog timer to while sleeping the processor for power saving, to turn on again after a set long-ish amount of time. If you're not using that then it doesn't matter. You can also ditch the JTAG and just use UART for programming, or vice-versa. That schematic was just showing a bunch of different peripherals you might want to have.

>>2542908
>Am I right in saying that this is a star configuration motor because it can be used with two voltages
It's a star configurations because there's a centre connection. It can be used with two voltages because they've split each winding into two. Either of those features can be present without the other.
>How can I measure the inductance when it is in this configuration?
You can't, because the windings are all connected together. You'd need to remove those connections before measuring. There should be a user-serviceable wiring box of some sort.
You may be able to do the measurements anyhow and calculate back what the equivalent single inductance should be, but that doesn't sound trivial. It might also be possible to calculate the inductance from the rated current at a known frequency, and probably also the ESR.
>numbers
Not sure, but they may well not be standardised. Follow the documentation for your motor in particular over anything else.
