>>2542952
Well if the plastic is that sensitive you have two options: 1 avoid soldering by using aligator clips or drilling a hole and then twist a wire around it
2. if soldering is a must, then your best bet is to minimize temperature and soldering time. To do so, first make sure that you use lead solder, not that lead-free crap since it requires higher temperature. Second, make sure to prepare the surface. it looks like this contact is corroded. So sandpaper it, then wash it as best as you can to make sure it takes solder easily and reduces the time it needs to be heated up. Second, try to solder as far away from the plastic as possible. If you can, try to solder on the top edges, since it will increase the time for the heat to transfer to the plastic. Finally, make sure that your wire is tinned properly before soldering, since an untined wire will increase solder time. That is all of course assuming you can't remove the plastic and can't buy spares if you screw up.it might also be useful to perhaps somehow cool the connector (bag of ice maybe?), just make sure that the water won't damage the connector. Try to also limit the amount of time you solder. If you see it's not soldering, after a second or two, stop and let it cool down, then prep the area again (sandpaper, flux, etc.) and try again.

I'd generally not put caps on the d+/- lines, just caps on the power rails. Though some further reading (https://github.com/myelin/modular-arm-usb/issues/7) seems to suggest that it's not a stupid idea. If you're making a PCB, make footprints for them and leave them unpopulated unless you get issues. Could add a jumperable footprint for a series resistor also (e.g. one with pads really close together so you can jumper the footprint with a solder blob). Same for the TVS diodes, they're a nice thing to add for a design that's more resilient against ESD and circuit faults, I'd make the footprint but leave it vacant unless you happen have the parts lying around. If you're proto-boarding things, then it shouldn't be too hard to modify your circuit to add caps and ZVS diodes, assuming they even make THT ZVS diodes.

FYI a common and cheap linear regulator used by lots of arduinos is the AMS1117-3.3, though I'm unsure how much I trust the ones from alibay (lost an AVR to one) so get them from a good source. If you want to run it off a lithium cell, then an HT7333 would be a better choice for its extremely low dropout.

>>2543165
that website is also mis-understanding the term.
voltage drop in electronics isn't the amount a voltage has gone down, it is the voltage that appears accross a conductor or circuit. you are talking about losses, due to resistance, there is a voltage drop accross some of those conductors but it doesn't mean what you think it means. lets say you are using that 16awg wire which you state has a 2% "voltage drop". the voltage drop accross that conductor is not only proportional to the length, but also the load connected, saying 2% means nothing without other parameters.
so lets imagine some other parameters;
load is 8ohms, wire is 2ohms. you end up with 80% of the voltage accross the load, if the supply voltage is 200 volts, the voltage drop of the wire is 20% so 40V, the load has a voltage drop of 160V.
Wouldn't surprise me if some institution or company started using a different definition, because the people who make new standards for electronics are totally fucking retarded.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2543173
I'm not an electronics guy and I don't understand why it's wrong to use it that way. I understand voltage drop to be what you would measure with e.g. a multimeter with a probe before and after a component in a live circuit. In this case I just treat both wires coming from the power supply, positive and negative as one for simplicity, but I would check the voltage drops of each wire individually and then add the voltage drops together to treat them as one.

This is how I manually calculated everything to see if I understand what I'm calculating is the same as these online calculators:

I make the assumption that the pump is running at its maximum rating, a 12V power supply with 3 amps flowing.
Assume I use 6 meters of 22 AWG copper wire, which has 54.7 ohms per km of wire (according to wiki), that is then 54.7/1000*6=0.3282 ohms for 6 meters of wire.
We know 3 amps must be flowing both through the wire and the pump, therefore the voltage drop accross the wire must be 3*0.3282=0.9846V and the voltage drop across the pump must be 11.0154V.

Therefore the voltage drop across the wire, for 22AWG and given the above parameters, in percent is 0.9846/12*100=8.205%.

>I think that’s all you need, but I don’t know the story with the boot pins.
From what I read since last time we spoke, I think I figured the bootstrap pins out. On reset (or boot up), the pins IO0,3,45,46 are read and sets some behavior of the ESP32

>The EN pin resets the board when pulled low. Fed through the R1,C2 RC circuit to add a delay upon initial power up to allow power line to stabilize.

>Upon reset, the IO45 is internally pulled low through a 45k resistor, and is responsible for setting VDD_SPI voltage (3.3v if pulled low or 1.8V if pulled high). This is not necessary for the wroom boards since the QSPI flash is included and there is a fuse that is permanently burned to set it to 3.3V (or 1.8V on some models). In this case, it's set to 3.3V through the permanent fuse and this IO port can be tied to whatever on boot and can be seen as just another IO pin

>Upon reset, the IO46 is internally pulled low through a 45k resistor, and is responsible for booting mode (SPI = run program, download = download new program). In the former case, IO46 can be either 0 or 1 (don't care bit) and in the latter, it must be 0. So pulling this pin low all the time will allow you to boot in whatever mode you want assuming the other pin (io0) is configured properly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2543878
1.5J in a volume of 95E-6 m^3, or 16000J/m^2. Polypropylene stores 6500J/m^3, so off by a factor of 2.4. I'm thinking it's still possible to be legit if you consider additions to the PP to increase its dielectric strength or permittivity.

You could consider making your own capacitors by buying sheets of a dielectric and layering them with aluminium foil, it's likely cheaper. If you pick a thermoset resin or molten thermoplastic you can make any thickness you want, though removing bubbles and ensuring the plates are set properly becomes a challenge. As an example, you could store your full amount of energy (13.5J) in about 1kg of white PLA, which costs only $30 or so, plus time. Each layer would be 0.09mm or so, you can probably print that out as a couple of layers.

The cell technology is specified as NiCd, but I don't think those are sold any more. The laptop also takes a 4-pin power supply with two different voltages: 12V and 9.5V. I have no idea which voltage goes on which pin and how many pluses and minuses there are (there is a chance I could find this out by disassembling the laptop, but I'm not very good with electronics so idk), and sourcing an original power supply for this model is pretty much impossible nowadays. Nevertheless, if I somehow happened to come into possession of a working charger, I would like to be able to charge the batteries inside the laptop and not have to use an external charger. My first thought was lithium-ion rechargeable batteries, but those don't seem to be sold in this form factor and voltage specification. The only stuff that matches the specification is nickel-metal hydrate batteries. I can get type Cs with 1.2V and they are rechargeable. The only problem is that I've read that NiMH batteries can only be used in place of NiCd batteries if they will not be charged inside the device. Different charging characteristics will make NiMh cells quickly deteriorate. At least that's what I've read, so I came here looking for confirmation and asking for better ideas if anyone has any. Going with NiMh would necessitate using an external charger, but chances of finding or making a working power supply for this thing are very slim as it is, so it's not a deal-breaker.

>>2543125 (me)
I've installed the pump and it's working well. If I run it for about 10 minutes the wires do get warm, but it actually only needs to run for about 30 seconds at a time and sometimes maybe 2 minutes. The worst case is about 10 minutes, so it'll be fine.

If anyone was wondering what it was for, it was for an automated system to make carbonated water. The membrane pump creates around 4.5-5.5 bar pressure from my mains water supply (2 bar) and forces filtered water into a keg with a float valve which also has a CO2 flask with a pressure reducer attached to it which is at 4 bar.

It works well and I now have continuous cooled carbonated water on tap coming out of my diy modified fridge.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2545203
That's really cool anon. Got any safety features? Like a water leak detector, thermal sensor, gas leak sensor, etc. Are you using gas from a welding cylinder, or something like a sodastream cylinder?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2545230
I thought about all that but realistically there's not much that can go wrong. I store syrups inside the fridge so whenever I open it I can see and hear if something is wrong and you can't overhear the pump because it's loud. The fridge has a hole at the back for condensation to escape. In case the fridge does flood and the door isn't forced open, that's where the water would escape and it would be very visible on the kitchen floor. The mains power supply is on a different shelf above and next to the fridge, so that water can't get anywhere near it, that's why I used a 3 meter long cable which feeds into the fridge.

Worst case the fridge gets flooded and with it the kitchen, but even so, relatively slowly because the filter (on top of the fridge, might mount on wall) and the 1/4 inch water pipe both already limit the water flow considerably. For the water connection I used the same 1/4 inch pipes and plug fittings that are used for those samsung fridges and we've been using those for at least 8 years and they're extremely reliable, never had any issues with this style of fittings. The small pump is hanging from the ceiling inside the fridge to reduce noise and also prevent water getting to it from the outside in case of a leak.
>Are you using gas from a welding cylinder, or something like a sodastream cylinder?
I use a 2kg CO2 flask, sodastream is overpriced. I don't worry about gas leaks because these don't contain enough CO2 to pose a threat and the kitchen is open + we air regularly. I also intend to fully check the system every half a year or so.

I'm going to add a 4-5 ampere inline fuse and a 77C thermal fuse which I will wrap with the wire, it's quite cheap and trivial to add and would be a good safety addition I think.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2541876
This is the effect people get when they jumper the 4 input Marshalls. On the left two channels are in parallel. Intuitively most of their overdrive is from abusing subsequent stages like the phase splitter and you've given them double the current available. Having 500k to ground on the right will attenuate some volume. You have a mild eq with that configuration.
High gain amps use several stages with controlled attenuation and bass or treble cuts. They also choose which sides of the signal to clip. If you were to series your stages instead, it becomes apparent why everything must be more tailored to your goals.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2546156
If you use diodes to prevent current from flowing back where it wouldn't belong then probably. But if you just use BMSs then if the D cell pack is a higher voltage, it could easily backflow into the lead-acid and drain itself. Even with diodes, whichever battery is a higher voltage will get drained by the load, so you'd have to set the maximum D cell voltage to be lower than the minimum lead-acid voltage. So instead of diodes, some power FETs or a contactor/relay of some sort to switch between the batteries (plus sufficient capacitance to make up for the jump) might be the way to go.

>>2546266
>>2546275
A lot of stuff in AoE will be superfluous to your end goal (e.g. power electronics, RF and transmission lines), but in general it would broaden your understanding of electronics anyhow. I recommend following along with AoE's labs too, but doing that all with a breadboard yourself may not be possible. There's always simulators if you need to get a bit of intuition as to how changing variables will affect a circuit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2546266
AoE is a reference book, it's not the best thing for beginners because lots of details are omitted with hand-waving (the Art part in AoE). For PCB (general purpose, no RF) design main things you need are
>passive component basics (RLC)
>network analysis, basic theorems, KVL, KCL, thevenin, norton, combinations, transformations
>signals and systems, transfer functions, feedback
That alone would be quite a lot for 2 months. Think of it as basic analog language that allows you to understand circuits. Then you need to add
>physics of electricity
>semiconductors
>digital systems
>thermal design
>... other things depending on your needs
Unless you're Korean kid that studies 16h/day it's probably best just to focus on passive components and network analysis. 2 months is basically nothing. I've studied electronics for 5 years in university and I still feel like a retard.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Welcome to the woodworking general, here we discuss the working of wood and the tools and techniques of working wood. So far we tend to be mostly hand tool folk with a slant towards cabinetry and carving but all are welcome and we have some capable power tool folk amount our ranks. General carpentry question such as framing/decking/general construction seems to get a better response in the /qtddtot/ or /sqt/.

>essential /wwg/ books
Tage Frid Teaches Woodworking, gives you everything you need and shows you how to do it multiple ways from hand tools to power tools and gives you the knowledge to determine which is best, and then he teaches you how to apply what you learned. The PDF of the second book can be found in the usual places, but the other two are MIA.
https://www.amazon.com/dp/1561588261

Christopher Schwarz tells you everything you need to know about planes and saws and their use
Handplane Essentials
https://www.amazon.com/dp/1440332983
Handsaw Essentials
Best to find this one in PDF from the usual sources, out of print and pricey!

Chris Pye wrote the book on carving and keeps on writing them.
https://www.chrispye-woodcarving.com/

The Eastern tradition, Japanese Woodworking Tools: Their Tradition, Spirit and Use by Toshio Odate
https://www.amazon.com/dp/0941936465

Leonard Lee The Complete Guide to Sharpeninig, how to sharpen most everything.
https://www.amazon.com/dp/1561581259

Bob Flexner - Finishing 101, covers the common stuff, his other books cover the uncommon and go into more depth
https://www.amazon.com/dp/1440308454/

Illustrated Cabinet Making by Bill Hylton, learn to design furniture that won't fall apart
https://www.amazon.com/dp/1565233697/

>essential /wwg/ tv
https://www.pbs.org/show/woodwrights-shop/
https://www.newyankee.com/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The USDA publishes the Wood Handbook: Wood as an Engineering Material, has some good info in it but the bulk of it is beyond what most woodworkers need and it is primarily concerned with wood used in construction so most of the info dealing with strength and the like would result in massive overkill. PDF is free to download from their site but getting an old edition for a couple dollars used is probably a better idea for most, less of the old editions is dedicated to things of no use to the woodworker, 1980s editions have a good balance. The section which deal with the structure and quality of wood/trees, how they grow and what that means to the woodworker is good knowledge to have.

wood-database.com is useful and may be all you need.

previous thread was very nice: >No.2532174

Topic: Show us your favorite tool in your shop or something you built.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2540554
Yes a planer can flatten stock. you just need a plywood or mdf sled and some wedges. you can turn pretty much anything into perfectly flat boards if you're ok with sacrificing some thickness.
>put wood on sled
>check to see how if it sits flat or woobles around
>use double sided tape and wedges to shim under wood so it sits firmly on sled
>shim under any parts that could deflect as the drive roll pushes the stock through the machine
>send through planer until top is flat
>flip over and send the other face of the stock through the planer
>no shims needed, it will come out dead flat

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2541449
Do as >>2541531 says and use a scraper. If you insist on planing it then assuming you're using a standard 45° bevel down plane, sharpen the absolute shit out of the chip breaker until any gap between the very point of it and the blade ceases to exist completely, then set it as close to the bevel as physically possible. That will give you a higher effective angle.
Alternatively you can put a back bevel on the iron to get it comfortably above 50° but that also means you'll have to grind it away when you no longer want that unless you have multiple blades.
For some planes you can buy different frogs with higher angles. If you hate yourself you might want to do that.
If you're using a bevel up plane, either buy a higher angle blade or put a higher angle on your current one.
In all cases you should make sure your iron is stupid sharp and know that all you're doing by raising the angle is mimicking the action of a scraper. Not saying it isn't useful in the future, just that softwoods are very prone to tearing and using a scraper every now and again isn't hard.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2541732
Just put it somewhere dryish, it will probably dry out in a week or two depending on its size. Wood that has been dried gives out its moisture fairly readily and curing wood where it gets wet actually makes it more stable in the long run because repeated wet dry cycles breaks down the hemicellulose more quickly.

>>2542195
Dunno bro, if you need to flatten a relatively large panel, you'd need a whole lot of machine to accomplish what you can do with one or two relatively cheap hand planes + a bench that you should have even if you work mainly with power tools. Hand planes and jointers/planers are not direct replacements for each other.

Personally, I'd still start with hand tools, since they are still way cheaper. Then get a jointer and planer just based on what deals I can find (maybe a table saw before either of these two as well). A used and very high quality hand plane should be easily findable for around $50 on E-bay, and often way cheaper than that in a local antique store or flea market. Yes, they take some learning, but there are tons of excellent materials on line.

So far, I have a couple hand planes and a 6" jointer (got a great deal from a coworker's aunt, who was trying to clean out her late husband's collection/hoarder stash).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2543092
>more consistent.
That's the problem, wood joints in general are not consistent in size, material qualities, angles involved, structural loads involved, tolerances, etc. That jig review/test spends a bunch of time choosing what amounts to compromises to fit the dowel length and depth parameters offered.
Meanwhile a tenon or spline/ biscuit can be made to fit any particular joint precisely to accommodate odd sizes and angles and usually with some degree of adjustment that dowels don't ever offer and makes a jig nearly imperative if you use them.
In many cases just setting up/testing a jig is more work than making another joint, including joints that eliminate separate tenons/splines/ bisquits/ dowels altogether, that make more and more sense the more you are getting into production runs where jigs are worth the extra hassle.
Finally, dowels don't scale particularly well along with stock sizes, always require multiples to resist torsional loads, and aren't conducive to the kind of dry fitting that makes for precise joints that mate perfectly when glued up and clamped.
They require a shit ton of precision that doesn't make the joint appreciably stronger, all so you can use one of a limited set of fixed dimension pins when joining a material that otherwise offers almost infinite dimensional choices for minimal effort. That includes the size, shape, location and depth of loose tenons, splines etc. but dowels, not so much.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2543077
Most of the tests you see for these are testing the splitting strength of which the dowel/domino/etc is in, not of the joint. Testing a joint requires thinking about how it fails. Dominos are much strong strong than dowels if the force is through the flat side since dowels concentrate the force where dominoes spread it.
>>2543092
Case in point, that is testing the wood's resistance to splinting, not the joint.Change the direction of force 90 degrees and dowels will be the worst performers by a long shot, not that this tells you anything about joints and how they fail. 99% of joints fail because seasonal wood movement slowly shears the wood's fibers in the joint until the glue is compromised. Do his tests without glue, see what happens, dowels will be much worse in all regards. Still not quite accurate but more accurate in that a failed dowel joint is more likely to cause damage to the surrounding wood than a failed mortise and tenon but over 90% of the time the joint is just going to come unglued because seasonal wood movement has sheared the wood fibers that the glue bonded too.

posts.com:
>>2543579
Scrapers and softwood produce a textured finish, the scraper compresses the soft summer wood and cuts the hard winter wood, the soft summer wood pops right back up. It is a nice finish and the traditional violin surface finish but not what most want.

Smooth finish on softwood is largely dependent on a properly set and tuned chipbreaker on a finely set iron. Mouth does not really matter since the softwood is perfectly happy compressing to fit through the mouth and tearing out anyways. I like a plane with a 50 degree angle for soft woods, lets you take a slightly bigger bite before tear out happens but 45 does the job just fine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2543924
Old dovetail planes tend to be steeper, not shallower but that does not really matter, I was just pointing this important bit of information out. Not everyone has a grinder or a honing jig that can deal with angles and fixing that angle is slow and not fun if you have to do it freehand.

If a 90 degree shoulder was bad then all router/dovetail plane cut sliding dovetails would fail. Undercutting is not needed as long as the dovetail is tight but undercutting sliding dovetails is just about making life easier when doing them with saw and chisel.

Tilting the plane to correct angle does not really work because of the fence unless you are going to go at the should with a chisel or side rabbet but that sort of defeats the ease of a dovetail plane.

Also, anons sliding dovetails are very much on show and visible from the top so being off by a degree or two will not look good, nor will undercuts. These are the apron to leg attachment on a glass topped table.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2544121
Im NTA either but FWIW a big problem with a lot of these discussions is that they begin with the premise that there's some ideal of a "well equipped shop" that can handle practically any process, when even in professional shops thats rarely the standard. Real world shops tend to be equipped for a far narrower range of processes and products than most people think of in the abstract when imagining a "well equipped shop".
Certain types of work benefit from having every conceivable process covered, like prototyping, signs and display work where fanciful aesthetic elements are to be expected...
but unless you *absolutely* need one, a bandsaw is a big investment and in many cases not having one is at worst a minor inconvenience that can be worked around pretty easily. Jointers fall in that category too.
It really comes down to what will be *produced*, the shop and tools are simply a means to that end and its very rarely the case that the ability to handle every potential process that falls under the heading of "carpentry" is needed or worth preparing for, the same way its pointless to equip a kitchen around procedures you have no need to be equipped for or can do another way if necessary.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2544135
I'm not trying to steer you away from a bandsaw, they're great to have...but for smaller projects in thin stock they can be overkill and for tight curves and decorative work a scroll saw may be a better choice...
Resawing tends to be pretty setup intensive if you want good results, and in general bandsaws need a lot of fiddling with blades and guides to get the full range of cuts they *can* do.
They're one of those tools that looks a lot easier to use than they really are and can take a lot of time to understand well enough to know how to address problems that pop up with any particular job or material.
Again, not saying they're bad but even if you have a nice one you may still find yourself using alternate methods to avoid the setup time/ hassle and risk of blade damage just for a cut or two.
Also FWIW, specifically with resawing the accuracy problems that come with cheap/small saws tend to be amplified, especially with making veneers and similar thin cuts. Unless you are making lots of stock that way a good table saw and feather boards and flipping the stock over will resaw about the same width boards as a typical 14" bandsaw at the extreme limit of its resawing capacity (about 6"), and with a lot less setup and testing and virtually no risk of damaging the saw blade.
I get wanting to diy everything but for resawing and surfacing, even if you need to do a lot of it it can be very expensive and labor intensive to be equipped to still get less than professional results.
Ultimately, even as a hobbyist time management is a major consideration if you really want to produce finished projects and aren't just killing time.
If you can afford a decent one and have the space, by all means get a bandsaw, just really do your research and be realistic about their capabilities and needs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2542178
Jointing wood by hand is less work than surfacing by hand so there is a good case for surface planer and a hand plane for jointing. But jointing by hand is more difficult than surfacing by hand since surfacing by hand does not require you to get those perfect 90s for your glue joint to match up proper. Also worth noting that surface planers suck on fancy and interlocked grain, so that is worth considering if you want to work a lot of crotch/figured/burl wood.
>>2544177
Resawing by hand is pretty easy for smaller projects where you don't need to resaw an 8' board and can just split that last foot and chop it off to get what you need for the current project. The long panel saws make short work of it but have a fairly wide kerf (nothing worse than a bandsaw with a resaw blade), frame saw have a nice fine kerf but are slower. For anything under 3" width I generally use a rip kataba, sits between panel saw and frame saw for speed and has a fine kerf but is heavily affected by type of wood because of the Japanese tooth geometry, can be almost as fast as the panel saw in some woods but is the slowest of the bunch in the really dense woods.

That twist is caused by growing with binding plants like honeysuckle wrapped around them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2544596
What's "best" depends a lot on the stones geometry and your skills and how much effort and money you want to put into it...
For rounder shapes, cabochons, etc. a metal bezel is strong and not necessarily too difficult, especially if you use existing shapes like tubes and cap-like metal parts as the basis...copper pipe caps can be modified pretty easily, and things like brass chair leg ferrules like picrel may also work with some tweaking, some may look too modern but they can be distressed and patina added to make them more rustic.
Leather and rawhide can also be stretched over certain stones and lashed in place to act as a bezel, this can be incorporated into a wrapped handle and looks very rustic.
Wire wrapping is another option that can look very ancient and wizard-ish.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2544622
picrel is a cane that uses a leather bezel with hemp lashing with a cheap decorative glass cabochon (melted marbles)...
the "stone" was epoxied on and the leather and hemp both had a bit of poly varnish added to the soak water to help make them more water resistand and stiff when dry.
The leather completely covered the stone and was then cut away to reveal it after everything set...done right these can greatly resemble an eyelid, and those glass blobs can be back painted to look like an eye, all of which really sells the mystikal wizard thing. You can also get hyper realistic animal eyes used in taxidermy and do them this way.

When it comes to sliding dovetails the plane will often be faster for the the male portion since you generally remove very little wood and it is just a few passes. If we were both doing a few drawer backs I will probably be done in the time it takes you to swap bits, set fence/depth and do test cut. You would catch up to me on time on the female portion and we would probably end up fairly close. When you get up to the larger sizes the female portion is generally quicker by hand if you can even get a bit that will fit your router to do the job.

But personally, I just prefer hand tools, less restrictive (it is rare I need a new tool/jig/bit for any given job), quieter, far less dust and effortless to throw the needed tools on the saw bench and go work outside. Also, it helps keep me from turning into a soft old boomer. I still have my router but it has been a decade or so since I last plugged it in.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2545316
>special tricks
Might seem like a no brainer but when making precision assemblies like furniture, casework/ boxes, etc. one key to keeping things square and properly aligned is to make any identical parts truly identical by cutting them all on the same tooling setups, preferably all with one saw cut when possible.
Example: If you need strips of wood that are all the exact length, you can cut one board that length and then rip the strips, which avoids minor deviations from cutting them to length separately and minimizes tearout. This is a good way to cut stock for table legs and similar uprights as well; you can do dadoes and tenon shoulders all at once and then separate the individual parts and (assuming your saw fences are square) all of the various cuts will be in the exact same line and the chances of built in wobble and un- square boxes are greatly reduced.
In some cases exactly identical parts can also act as guages that determine spacing without the need to measure beyond the initial cuts to size them.
Basically, eliminate as many separate measurements as you can, every time you measure and cut is a chance to introduce variations.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2546531
>most wood workers (even pros) are not going to have enough clamps for 300 cutting boards

For that kind of mass production of glued up planks or panels you make a jig or set up a table with parallel rails and use long tapered paired wedges to create clamping pressure from one side, pic related.
You also make them up in as large a length as you can for each glue up; if you are making 16×20 cutting boards you make one glued up plank that's 16" by five feet plus the width of the two saw cuts to make it into three pieces after the glue cures, and put that extra space where the cross cuts will be.
Gang up 4 on one 80" plank and you're doing 75 glue up operations instead of 300.

>>2547723
Ok, lets look at the numbers and we will be generous to the wood worker.

We will say $5 a board foot for a suitable hardwood of a quality that will not have much in the way of rejects and we will assume no rejects, which means 4/4 rough sawn and you probably will not manage that. Say 1 board foot per cutting board and the wood worker gets $5 a board. Say $300 for consumables, (thickness sander belts, jointer/planer knives, disc sander discs (for cleaning up end grain) saw blade, finishing supplies, etc). So that means $1200. If you can manage to make all 300 in 40 hours (you won't) that means you make $30 an hour, you are now making what any decent wood worker would make at a cabinet shop.

Realistically you will make closer to $15 an hour if you are good (assuming you get that $5 a board which you almost certainly will not in this case) when all is said and done which is a far cry from the $100-200 an hour most wood workers make. Fine for the hobbyist or someone just starting out but not good for anyone with any sort of established reputation.

Even if I had no jobs lined up (which is often the case) I would not bother with such poor pay since it could very well cause me to have to pass on a non-shit job that is far more likely to lead to more work that is shit pay piece work.
